newsitem.title: USA: Eastern Gulf of Mexico gathering systems to merge.
newsitem.headline: Eastern Gulf of Mexico gathering systems to merge.

text.p: PanEnergy Corp said Dauphin Island Gathering Partners and Main Pass Gas Gathering Co have agreed to combine their two offshore natural gas gathering systems in the Gulf of Mexico, effective December 31.

The owners of the combined systems have approved expansion plans to construct about 78 miles of 24-inch diameter gas gathering line, which will provide an additional 500 million cubic feet per day of capacity for a total gathering capacity of 1.15 billion cubic feet daily, PanEnergy said.
The expansion will be installed in two phases.

The initial phase of the expansion is expected to provide some 200 million cubic feet daily of firm natural gas gathering service by the end of the third quarter of 1997. The second phase, with an additional 300 million cubic feet per day of firm natural gas gathering service, is expected to be completed during the winter of 1997-98.

The combined systems will be owned by a partnership comprising PanEnergy, with a 37.3 percent interest; MCN Corp with 34.6 percent; Coastal Corp with 13.6 percent; Consolidated Natural Gas Co with 13.6 percent; and Dauphin Island Gathering Co LP, the managing partner, an affiliate of Offshore Energy Development Corp with a one percent interest. The name of the partnership will be Dauphin Island Gathering Partners.

The existing Dauphin Island system is located in the Mobile and upper Viosca Knoll Areas, offshore Alabama. It is comprised of 90 miles of pipeline designed to gather up to 355 million cubic feet per day.

The existing Main Pass gathering system is in the Main Pass Area East, offshore Louisiana, and the lower Viosca Knoll Area, offshore Alabama, and consists of 57 miles of pipeline, designed to gather 300 million cubic feet daily.

The combined gathering systems will provide access to the interstate pipeline grid through three onshore Alabama interconnects and through Texas Eastern Transmission Corp in the southern Louisiana and Venice areas.
Some 2 to 3 trillion cubic feet of natural gas reserves are estimated to be recoverable in this area.
